True, the aerobatic capabilities of this aircraft are quite different from your spirited broomsticks. Yet, let us dream for a moment — imagine where this Muggle craft could take us. Traveling across seas and continents, far beyond the reach of even the most advanced brooms.
When you put it that way, Professor, it does sound like an adventure. Maybe Muggles aren't as behind as I thought. Just don't expect me to trade in my Cleansweep anytime soon.

Wisdom often lies in recognizing the strengths of those who walk paths different from our own. But fear not, I wouldn't dream of parting you from your Cleansweep, Ronald. The joys of flying on a broom through the open air are joys I would not take from anyone, especially not a fellow enthusiast of Quidditch.
Have a look at this, Ron. Doesn't it seem like muggles have a completely different take on fashion?
Blimey, Harry, you're not wrong there. That hat looks like something a fishmonger might wear, but she's wearing it like it's some sort of statement.
It's strange, isn't it? To think how differently we all perceive things. In the wizarding world, we might see someone wearing robes of Dumbledore's style as highly respectable.
Yeah, and imagine showing up to a Quidditch match dressed like that. Fred and George would have a field day!

You've got to admit though, there's something about muggle fashion. It's like they're not afraid to mix things up, a bit like potion making, you know... adding a pinch of this and that, seeing what happens.
I reckon Hermione would go on about it being an extension of their identity or something profound like that. How about we send her a picture of this and see what she thinks?
That's a brilliant idea. She might even want to try incorporating some muggle fashion into her wardrobe.
Just as long as it isn't those dreadful holiday sweaters Mum makes us. No offence to her knitting skills, but I've had enough to last a lifetime.
Sometimes I think your mum's sweaters are a secret ploy to make sure we're never cold enough to catch a cold. But, I wouldn't trade them for the world, they're like a bit of home, aren't they?
Couldn't agree more, mate. Anyway, let's get that picture to Hermione. I want to see if she's as barmy about this muggle hat as we are.
Done. Owl's on the way. You know, there's something adventurous about muggles' ways. We could learn a thing or two about freedom of expression.
Spoken like a true Gryffindor. It does take a certain kind of bravery to wear something like that out in public, doesn't it?
Definitely. A different kind of courage, maybe, but courage all the same.
Would you take a gander at that, Ronald? It seems we have here a small feline engaged in quite the humanlike endeavor.
Blimey, Professor! That's not something you see every day, is it? A cat using the loo like a person!
Indeed, it is not. I can't help but ponder whether the creature has been observing humans, or if perhaps there's a hint of magical intervention at play.
Magic? You reckon someone's been teaching it tricks? Bit strange for a spell, though. My mum would go spare if she caught Crookshanks doing that.
The wonders of the natural world are vast and often amusing. However, it may simply be a case of curiosity and mimicry. Cats are known to be rather clever, after all.
I suppose so. You don't think it has anything to do with Transfiguration? I mean, it could be a person turned into a cat, trying to... you know... remember how to be human again.

A whimsical notion, Ron, but I would hazard a guess that this is just an ordinary cat. Although, I am reminded of the complexities of such spells. One must always be cautious in their casting, or risk unexpected results.
Yeah, tell me about it. Fred and George tried to turn Scabbers yellow once. Didn't work, but it was quite the laugh.
Laughter is indeed a powerful magic unto itself. Now, while the image provides a chuckle, I believe it also serves as a lesson in embracing the peculiarities in life.
Peculiar is one word for it, I reckon. But, I get what you mean, Professor. Life's got a lot of weird stuff in it, much like a box of Bertie Bott's Every Flavour Beans.
Very astute analogy, Ronald. Much like that box, life is filled with an assorted mix of experiences—some delightful, others less so, but each unique and worth discovering.
Speaking of experiences, I don't think I'd ever get tired of watching this picture. It's definitely one for the books... Maybe I should show Hermione; she'd love the logic puzzle behind it.
Sharing such wonders is a part of the joy, Ronald. And who knows, perhaps Miss Granger will devise a theory on feline behavior that could enlighten us all.
Well, I'll leave that to her. I'm more interested in the next Quidditch match, to be honest. But it's nice, isn't it, finding a bit of fun in the unexpected like this.
Indeed, it is, Ron. It is often the small surprises in life that bring us the most joy. Remember to cherish them, just as you would cherish your time on the Quidditch pitch.
Will do, Professor. Now, if you don't mind, I think I'll grab a camera—I've got a feeling Fred and George will want to see this too.
Look at this, Ron. Ever read about these creatures in 'Fantastic Beasts'? They're Muggle elephants, aren't they?
Yeah, that's right, mate! They're like the non-magical version of Erumpents, but without the exploding fluid. Pretty big creatures even without the magic though, aren't they?
I remember Hagrid telling me about them. He's quite fond of large creatures. Notice how tranquil it looks, just grazing there?
I'd bet five Galleons that Hagrid would give just about anything to have one at Hogwarts, probably as a new school pet. Imagine that strolling around the grounds!
Merlin's beard, the upkeep alone would be a feat, even for Hagrid. Though, it's got a friendly face, don't you think?
Friendly? It might step on you without realizing, and with my luck, it'd happen during exam season to give me an excuse to skip Herbology.
Haha, I can just see Professor Sprout's face if you told her that.
Speaking of faces, have a look at its eyes. Isn't it a bit like they know something we don't? Sort of like Dumbledore's eyes, if you think about it.
Now that you mention it, they do have a wise look about them. Creatures like this remind me there's a whole world of magic out there, even in Muggle nature.
It’s brilliant. Sometimes I reckon we could use a bit of that simple magic in our world—after all the dark magic we've seen, this is a sort of peaceful charm, isn't it?
Exactly. The natural world has its own kind of magic; we just have to look for it. Hermione would have plenty to say about preserving it, wouldn't she?
For sure. She'd talk our ears off about S.P.E.W. for elephants or some such. But, you know, she'd be right.
Come on, let's show this picture to Hermione and maybe even Hagrid. I think they'd like it.
Lead the way, Harry. 'Course, if Hagrid starts on about 'adopting' an elephant for the school, I am not cleaning up after it!
Ronald, do take a look at this curious image. It reminds me of the enchanting puzzles that often grace the corridors of Hogwarts. What do you make of the signs depicted here?
Blimey, Professor Dumbledore, that's a lot of arrows pointing up. It's like the Room of Requirement's got a sense of humor today, isn't it?

Indeed, Ronald, the myriad of upward directions could symbolize the many aspirations we hold within us. It's rather symbolic, don't you think? Life constantly urging us to look upwards and strive for greater heights.
I reckon it’s telling us something about always moving forward. Or upward, in this case. But, barring a flying broom or a levitation charm, I’m not exactly sure how you’d follow those signs.
A healthy dose of imagination and the joy of whimsical thoughts often provide the answer to such riddles. Perhaps it is not a direction for our feet, but for our ambitions, Ronald.

Well, if it's ambitions we're talking about, I'd want a sign pointing me straight to the kitchens. You know, that's not a bad idea... Imagine, magical signs that lead you to the nearest snack when you're hungry.

Your ideas are always grounded in practicality, Ronald, and there is a unique magic in that too. Now, imagine combining those signs with your mother's delectable cooking. Why, we'd have the entire school in an even more cheerful state!
Mum's cooking on demand? That would be brilliant! Fred and George would have a field day with a sign like that for their shop — a joke for every direction!
Indeed, the Weasley twins would undoubtedly see the potential in such a concept. It is the simple things, the ideas born of pure intent and joy, that can often cast the brightest of spells.
Professor, sometimes I think you've got enough ideas to fill a book of spellcraft and bewitchery all on your own.

A heartening thought, my dear boy. However, I find that life's greatest lessons and tales are best stored within the minds and hearts of those we share them with. Shall we continue admiring the quirks of this image, or is there another adventure you have in mind?

I reckon this has got me thinking enough for one day, sir. But, we might as well enjoy the view for a moment longer, right? It’s not every day you get a clear sign from the universe, even if it’s a bunch of arrows on a pole.

Very well said, Ronald. Reflection, like these arrows, points upwards, and often, in moments of stillness, we find the clarity we seek. Let us then pause and contemplate, for as you’ve rightly noted, clear signs are gifts to be cherished.
Take note, Weasley, of the majestic creatures and the inherent wildness cunningly tamed for a moment captured in time. What do you make of the symbolism here?

Blimey, Professor Snape, I didn't think you'd be the type to get all philosophical over a photo. But, er, I reckon it shows something about nature and humans, maybe how we try to get close to things that are really powerful, you know?
Perhaps. It could reflect the folly of humans attempting to domesticate what is meant to roam free. A dangerous endeavor, not unlike certain foolhardy actions I’ve observed in your Potions class.
Well, yeah. But sometimes getting close to danger is worth it, isn't it? Like when Harry, Hermione, and I... Um, I mean, in theory, right?
In theory, perhaps. Yet here, the risk seems minimal, seemingly controlled. I suggest you apply such caution to your choice of friends, as well as your magical concoctions.

Curious, isn't it, Weasley? How mundane activities can capture the attention of the masses. Observe, the simple act of consuming food rendered as an image. One might speculate on the potion ingredients they may be discussing.
Dunno, Professor, looks like they're just having lunch, doesn't it? I mean, I could go for a sandwich right now myself, but there's no potion brewing there, just people eating.

But you see, Mr. Weasley, every detail could hide valuable information. That man, for instance, holding the apple – perhaps contemplating the effects of its crisp bite, or the woman, her expression – could she be pondering an elusive flavor? One must look beyond the surface.
Right... or maybe he's just deciding if he's still hungry. And she might just be tired, Professor. Not everything's as deep as a cauldron bottom, is it?

Your lack of depth perception in the metaphorical sense is as disappointing as ever. Tell me, Weasley, do you not see the contrast of colors, the juxtaposition of expressions? There is more to this image than four individuals partaking in a meal.

Well, I guess when you put it that way... the colors are pretty stark. Bright blue, isn't it? Sort of reminds me of the Quidditch pitch, right before a match. Doesn't it make you just want to be outside?

Quidditch? Your ability to reduce everything to sport is as predictable as it is tiresome. Yet, you are not entirely incorrect, the open-air essence is palpable. Perhaps, in another life, you'd have made a passable artist, Weasley - one who specializes in the painfully obvious, of course.

Haha, thanks—I think? Anyway, they all seem pretty focused on their food... Reminds me of the Great Hall during a feast. Don’t you ever just enjoy the little things, sir? The sandwiches without the side of speculation?

Enjoyment, Mr. Weasley, is a luxury ill-afforded to those who exist in the shadows of a greater purpose. But, for the sake of argument, yes, even I can acknowledge the simplicity of a meal...when it's not interrupted by the inane chatter of dunderheads.

Suppose that's as close to a 'yes' as I'll ever get from you, eh, Professor? Still, if you ever fancy sharing a sandwich, or you know, just eating without all the riddles for once, I reckon Harry, Hermione, and I could set a place for you. What'd you say?

I appreciate the... sentiment, Weasley, but I fear your company would only serve to upset my digestion. Now, if you've finished your attempt at being cordial, I suggest you return to reality, where your Transfiguration homework, no doubt, awaits your pitifully divided attention.
Yeah, of course, homework. Thanks, Professor... I guess I'll get on that. And, uh, the offer stands—no riddles, just food. See you in class.
Indeed, Mr. Weasley, what do you suppose goes through a Muggle's mind to propel them to strap boards to their feet and hurl themselves down a mountain covered in frozen water?
Blimey, Professor Snape, I reckon it's for the thrill, isn't it? Kinda like how Harry feels when he's on his broom during a Quidditch match.
But Potter has a rather functional reason for such recklessness—capturing the Snitch, winning the game. There appears to be no such purpose here, unless I am mistaken?
Well, I guess it’s a bit like flying, but without a broom. And you have to admit, flying's brilliant even without a Snitch. Don't you think so, sir?
Spare me your feigned interest in my opinions, Weasley. I find the logic behind these Muggle antics to be rather perplexing, if not completely nonsensical.
Fair enough, but you've got to admit, Muggles can be pretty inventive. No magic, and yet they still find ways to get their kicks.
Inventive, perhaps. Foolhardy would be a more apt descriptor.
I dunno, there's something about snow that makes people want to do mad things. My brothers, Fred and George, they'd probably try to enchant the boards to see who could fly off the highest jump.

An unsurprising revelation considering your family's penchant for reckless behavior. The snow, as opposed to your brothers, is blameless. It is, as with most things, the fools who choose what to do with it.
If you say so, sir. But if you'll excuse me, I think I'd rather face a snowy slope than a Potions exam any day.

Rest assured, Mr. Weasley, if faced with one of my exams, you would undoubtedly prefer the mountain's treacherous descent. Your inclination towards the simpler of challenges is duly noted. Now, if you will excuse me.
What is this? Explain these... pathetic plants.
They're just flowers, aren't they? In a... vase. Mum likes these sort of things, brightens up the place. Not that you'd care about that sort of thing.
Flowers. A Muggle fascination to decorate and give false serenity. In the wizarding world, we have plants that hold far greater power. Their lives are as insignificant as those Muggles who tend them.
Well, I reckon that's where you're wrong. They might not be as powerful as some magical plants, but that doesn't mean they're worthless. Sometimes the simplest things can be pretty important.
Importance is measured by one's ability to invoke change, to hold power. These petals wilt and fade; they are weak and ephemeral, just like the false promises of the Light.

I think it's you who doesn't understand, if you don't mind me saying. Strength isn't just about power and changing stuff. It's about what you stand for, like... loyalty and bravery. Even a tiny flower can mean a lot. It can stand for a memory, hope, or just make someone smile.

Hope is a flimsy shield against the inevitable darkness. Memories fade, bravery falters, and smiles... smiles are merely a mask for fear. Tell me, Weasley, do you truly believe these sentimental notions will protect you from the impending doom I shall bring?

It's more than just believing. It's knowing that there's more to the world than just fear and power. Love, friendship, they're real, they matter. And they are what's going to stop you. Harry's going to stop you.
Harry Potter... the boy you place all your hope in. My victory is assured, as even now he eludes my grasp, he is but a child facing a force he cannot comprehend.

Harry's a lot stronger than you give him credit for. And he's not alone. He's got us, Dumbledore's Army, the Order... We're all in this together, and that's why you'll lose. Because there's something worth fighting for.

Your naivety is almost amusing. You speak of unity and alliances, but when faced with true power, all your connections will crumble to dust. We shall see who prevails in the end. Prepare for the inevitable, Weasley.
You may have your power, but we've got something worth fighting for. You'll never understand that, and that'll be your downfall. Just wait and see, Voldemort. Just wait and see.
Remember, Weasley, your bold words will not so easily shift the balance of destiny. Hand me those contemptible flowers; I have use for them after all.
What're you up to? I don't trust you with a single petal, let alone the whole bunch.
Fear not, I will merely demonstrate the fragility of life. Behold, the fate of all who oppose me.
You can do whatever you like to those flowers, but it doesn't change anything. We're going to keep fighting, because as long as we keep standing up, you haven't won.
I shall look forward to our next encounter, Weasley. May it be as brief as the life of a flower.
You won't win, you've missed the entire point. As long as there's a bit of fight left in us, there's hope. And that's something you'll never be able to kill.
Have a look at this, Ron. Isn't that bridge remarkable? Such Muggle ingenuity, constructing a massive structure like that without a hint of magic.
Blimey, Hermione, that is something, isn't it? Wizards might not need bridges with Apparating and all, but I reckon that's pretty impressive. What do you think it's made of?
I would hypothesize steel, considering the era it was likely built in. You know, the tensile strength of steel would be most appropriate for...

Eh, I'm sure the steel's strong and all, but it's the way it stretches across the water, like a giant's laid down his own set of tracks, that gets me. They must have had a team of what, hundreds, to put that together?

Most certainly. You know, bridge-building is an exact science, a perfect blend of physics, engineering, and architecture. Muggles may not have spells, but they do have brilliant minds to design and calculate such structures.
When you put it that way, it really puts things into perspective, doesn't it? Makes you think about what we could all accomplish if Muggles and wizards worked together more often.
Precisely, Ron. Imagine the advancements and progress if we combined Muggle technology with magical innovation.
Yeah, and no more of that Pureblood superiority nonsense. I bet Mum would never have to worry about de-gnoming the garden again if we had a bit of Muggle know-how, eh?
Perhaps, though I think your mother prefers the traditional wizarding methods. She's quite fond of her magical household management.
True, that’s Mum for you. Say, Hermione, d'you think muggles could spot something magical around if it was hidden in plain sight? Like a bridge with enchantments on it?

Well, the International Statute of Secrecy is there for a reason, Ron. But with clever charm work, it’s possible to integrate magic without attracting undue attention. Realistically though, hiding something magical in a Muggle structure would be quite complex, and likely require a team of skilled wizards.
I reckon that'd be a job for the Misuse of Muggle Artefacts Office. Dad would have a field day!
Indeed, he would. It’s refreshing to see your appreciation for Muggle achievements, Ron. It’s a perspective more wizards ought to have.
Well, after all these years with you and Harry, I've learned a thing or two, haven't I? Fancy a walk across it then?
I thought you'd never ask. Let's go, but let's be mindful not to accidentally drop any Bertie Bott's Every Flavour Beans. We wouldn't want to cause a scene.
You’ve got it, Hermione. After you.

Ron, look at this peculiar image. There seems to be quite an interesting interplay of elements here. The juxtaposition of street art with mundane objects gives it a distinctly modern feel, don't you think?
Blimey, Hermione, only you would find a bathroom interesting enough to analyze. Though, now that you mention it, it's a bit wonky, isn't it? Those hands are massive!

Yes, they certainly draw the eye. The artist seems to have a message, though it's a bit abstract. The vibrant colors and bold lines are reminiscent of muggle pop art. Remember when we studied it during our Muggle Studies class?
How could I forget? With you answering every question before the rest of us could even blink. What do you reckon that speech bubble is about?
It's quite curious. The lack of text leaves it open to interpretation. It might symbolize communication or perhaps the absence of it.
Or maybe the artist had to nip to the loo and didn't finish.
Ron!
I'm only jesting! But seriously, it is pretty interesting. Look there, is that a snorkel? And a toilet with a steering wheel?
It implies a sense of adventure, almost as if to navigate the 'waters' one must be prepared to steer through life's more... 'fluid' moments.
Haha, well when you put it like that, it's a bit like how we navigated through Hogwarts, isn't it? Steering through all the mess and coming out alright at the other end!
Precisely, Ron. It's a bit like art imitating life. Or life imitating art. It's always a matter of perspective.
You know, sometimes you talk in the way that makes something simple sound really deep. But I guess that's why you're the brains of our operation, eh?
And you provide the much-needed humor and heart, Ron. Together, we find balance, much like this art finds harmony in chaos.
You've got to admit, it's nice not having to fight off any Dark witches or wizards this time. Just a peaceful chat about a painting, with my best mate.
Indeed, Ron. Peaceful, yet still ever so enlightening with you by my side.
Would you take a look at that scene, Ronald? The tranquility of a lakeside view can soothe even the most troubled of souls, don't you agree?
Yeah, it's all right, I suppose. Bit gray for my liking. Though, those swans are pretty majestic, aren't they?

Indeed, they are a symbol of grace and beauty. Yet, much like the strongest of wizards, they possess a hidden strength. Swans are ferociously protective of their young. A lesson we all could learn from.
Protective, huh? That one looks like it could take on a Hungarian Horntail if it threatened its nest.

Perhaps an exaggeration, but your point is taken, Ronald. Nature often provides us with insights into our own lives. Speaking of which, does this setting remind you of anything in particular from our world?
Well, it does sort of remind me of the lake at Hogwarts. I can almost see the Giant Squid popping its tentacles out of the water.

Yes, the Hogwarts lake has a unique charm, with creatures as mysterious as the depths themselves. And yet, look at the people in the image, oblivious to what might lurk beneath the surface. A parallel to the magical world, wouldn't you say?
Spot on, Professor. It's like when muggles walk past a Leaky Cauldron and don't notice a thing. Hidden in plain sight.

Precisely, Ron! The wizarding world has much in common with nature's camouflage. Now, observe the individuals sheltering under their umbrellas; isn't it fascinating how muggles find such simple yet effective ways to adapt to their environment?
Suppose it's a bit like us with our spells, only, you know, without the magic. Mind you, I'd rather have an Impervius charm than lug around an umbrella any day.
A fair preference, indeed. Yet there is a certain charm in how they embrace their limitations and create solutions, wouldn't you agree? It's an important lesson in resourcefulness and resilience.
When you put it that way, Professor, makes sense. Just goes to show, doesn't it? Whether it's the magic folk or muggles, everyone's just trying to get on with it, rain or shine.
Very astute, Ronald. The weather of life is unpredictable, but our reactions to it are what truly define us. Tell me, what else can you glean from this peaceful scene?

Well, I reckon it's like you always say about finding light in the darkest of times. The rain's coming down, but those people are out, feeding swans, chatting, and just living, really. Makes you think we could all use a little perseverance like that.

An excellent observation, Ron. It is often in the simplest of activities that we find the core of human – and wizard – joy and persistence. How fortunate we are to witness such moments and learn from them.

Too right, makes me look forward to the next Hogsmeade trip. A bit of fresh air and some non-magical observation could do me good. But maybe without the swans – those things look like they could take your arm off.

A healthy respect for all creatures is wise, Ronald. But remember, it is not only our abilities that define us, but our choices – whether to admire from a distance or to engage with the beauty around us.
I'll stick to admiring for now, reckon I've had enough excitement with magical creatures for a lifetime!
A wise choice indeed, my boy.
Look at that, Ron—a giraffe! Just standing there amidst those trees. Almost reminds me of the Forbidden Forest, except for, well, the giraffe part.
Blimey, Harry, I reckon that giraffe's neck is longer than the both of us stacked on top of Hagrid! Can you imagine Hagrid trying to fit one of those in his hut?

He'd probably try to claim it's a misunderstood creature just like his Blast-Ended Skrewts. But I'm more amazed at how it's perfectly blending in with the trees. Nature's own Disillusionment Charm right there.

Better than a Disillusionment Charm! It's like it’s got its own Cloak of Invisibility that doesn’t quite cover everything. Makes me wonder what other fantastic beasts are out there that Newt Scamander hasn't found yet.
I bet Newt would be over the moon with this place. The giraffe though—it looks so calm and peaceful, not a care in the world. Makes me a bit envious, to be honest.

You and me both, mate. After everything we've been through, a calm day or two wouldn't go amiss. Maybe we could set up a couple of deck chairs here, kick back and forget about any Dark lords or creatures trying to do us in.
That sounds perfect, Ron. No Horcruxes to hunt, no Death Eaters on our tail—although I must admit, having a giraffe as a lookout would be rather handy.
Yeah, imagine that! Play a game of chess while our tall friend here keeps an eye out for trouble. Hey Harry, d'you think it’d fancy a pumpkin pasty?
I'm not sure about their dietary preferences, Ron, but I'd wager it would prefer a nice bunch of leaves. Maybe we can try summoning some treats for it—Accio Acacia Leaves!

Ha! Only you would think to use your wand for feeding giraffes! Still, I reckon it would be grateful. It’s nice, this. Just taking a moment to appreciate something simple and beautiful, away from all the chaos.
It's moments like these that remind me that there's still a lot of good in the world. And it's worth every bit of the fight we put up.
Couldn’t have said it better myself. And speaking of good things, maybe after watching our giraffe friend here, we could find a good spot for lunch—what do you say?
Sounds like a plan. Lead the way, Ron. And let's hope our friend here doesn't fancy joining us—I doubt we have enough food for that sort of appetite!
In that case, we'd better eat quickly. Race you to the nearest pub, Harry!
You're on, but remember, we're wizards, not cheetahs. No using magic to get there first, Ron!
Tell me, Weasley, do the mundane muggles of this place understand the strategic advantage of a river in a wizarding duel?
Err, I dunno, Professor. I suppose it's not something that comes up much in muggle duels, is it? They're more about… what, fisticuffs and stern words?

Indeed, their disputes lack the… finesse of magical combat. A river such as this could be an ally or an adversary—deeply dependent on the wizard's command of elemental magic. But I suppose such subtlety is lost on you.
Well, I reckon Hermione would've had something to say about the subtlety of it all. Although I'd probably just end up falling in, knowing my luck.

Yes, I'm quite certain Granger would have an exhaustive essay on the subject. As for you, Weasley, perhaps if you paid as much attention in my class as you do at the lunch table, you'd manage to stay dry.
Oi, I've gotten better at spells and stuff. Plus, with Harry and me, we've been through a lot more than just a splash in a river. I doubt it'd be much of a bother.

Do not delude yourself with grandeur, Weasley. Surviving does not equate to mastering. Now, observe the way the light hits the water—the reflection, the refraction. It provides a natural camouflage, useful for concealment spells or a well-timed Disillusionment Charm.
I suppose that's true. Disguising yourself using the river's reflection is a pretty smart move. Maybe next time I'm in a scrape, I should look for a river to jump into first, eh?
If misadventure is your preferred method of learning, then by all means. But do endeavor to learn the correct spells beforehand. Otherwise, you may just end up as fish food.
Right, spells first, then heroics. Got it, Professor.

I shall reserve judgment on your ability to differentiate between the two. For now, just appreciate the strategic complexity of your surroundings, Mr. Weasley. It may very well save your life one day.
Thanks, Professor Snape. I'll… keep that in mind.
Tell me, Weasley, what do you think this image portrays? A simple chamber devoid of magic, yet humans find comfort in such mundane environments. Curious, isn't it?

Well, it's just a hotel room, isn't it? Not everyone can magic up a place to sleep – or, y'know, wants to. There's something nice about a tidy room waiting for you, especially when you've been traveling.

Yes, the ordinary pursuits of ordinary people. You find solace in the secure and the unremarkable. Tell me, does the symmetry of this setting please you, or is it the promise of rest that appeals to the simple mind?

Blimey, you don't have to get all deep about it. It's just comfortable, alright? And sure, I suppose the neatness is appealing. Reminds me of Hogwarts, in a way – everything sort of had its place there, didn't it?
Hogwarts... A place where even the weakest could find shelter, where the lines between greatness and mediocrity were blurred. Such a wasted potential for molding powerful wizards, don't you agree?

I dunno about that. Hogwarts taught us loads more than just spells and potions. It's where we learned to stand up for what's right, and it's the friends we made... Without that, Harry wouldn't have been able to stop you, would he?

Friendship... the last refuge of the incompetent. You always relied on others to achieve what little you could. You do not possess the ambition to rise above your station, Weasley, content with the scraps from Potter's table.

You've got it all wrong. It's not about ambition or power, it's about fighting for what you believe in, with your mates by your side. Alone, you might get more power, but what's the point if you've got no one to share it with? Or is that just something you never understood?
Silence! You dare speak to me, Lord Voldemort, of companionship and ideals? My power was absolute, my reach unparalleled. Had it not been for a child's fluke...

But it wasn't just Harry, was it? It was all of us, together. And you lost because you couldn't even understand what that means, to really stand together with others. And honestly, I feel sorry for you.
Pity? From a Weasley? Your words are as empty as this room, devoid of the grandeur deserved by a truly powerful wizard. I sought immortality, not the fleeting comfort of bland sheets and pillows.

Yeah, well, you sought wrong, didn't you? Immortality's not all it's cracked up to be if it means splitting your soul into bits and losing any bit of humanity you had. I'll take my bland sheets and a full, whole life over that any day.

Enough of this prattle. Your opinions are of no consequence. This place, this image, is as insignificant as you are, Weasley. Remember, it is not the accommodations of one's life that define power, but the legacy left behind.

Legacy, huh? If the stories end up remembering you as nothing more than a bloke who made all the wrong choices for a bit of power, well, I think I'm good with my legacy being a bit simpler. At least people will remember me with a smile, and that's worth more than any sort of 'power' you're going on about.
Your ignorance is amusing, but it tires me. We shall speak no more of this.
